problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_items_fit_in_assigned_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        pos: Position = positions[i]
        item: Item = items[i]
        assert pos.x + item.width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert pos.y + item.height <= BOX_HEIGHT

ensure_items_fit_in_assigned_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping conditions
                assert (positions[i].x >= positions[j].x + items[j].width or 
                        positions[j].x >= positions[i].x + items[i].width or 
                        positions[i].y >= positions[j].y + items[j].height or 
                        positions[j].y >= positions[i].y + items[i].height)

no_overlap_constraints(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= 20

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments)

# --- Objects ---


Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=40),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=40)
})

Position = DSRecord({
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=40),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=40)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT: int = 40
BOX_WIDTH: int = 40
ITEMS: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 34, "height": 13}, {"width": 5, "height": 32}, {"width": 6, "height": 13}, {"width": 32, "height": 33}, {"width": 22, "height": 6}, {"width": 29, "height": 34}, {"width": 15, "height": 20}, {"width": 23, "height": 17}, {"width": 2, "height": 23}, {"width": 18, "height": 9}, {"width": 9, "height": 31}, {"width": 29, "height": 14}, {"width": 5, "height": 35}, {"width": 14, "height": 11}, {"width": 6, "height": 6}, {"width": 12, "height": 29}, {"width": 4, "height": 28}, {"width": 3, "height": 1}, {"width": 3, "height": 24}, {"width": 14, "height": 13}]
N_ITEMS: int = 20
nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)
item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
N_ITEMS : int = 20
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 20
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 20


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> int:
    max_box_used: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i] > max_box_used:
            max_box_used = assignments[i]
    return max_box_used

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

def fit_items_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),

        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width

fit_items_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlap: if any of these conditions is true, there's no overlap
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

# Leave empty, if not required.

def ensure_item_assignment_and_position_uniqueness(
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
):
    # Each item must be assigned to exactly one box (already implied by domain of assignments)
    # Positions are unique per item (structurally guaranteed by list indexing)
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure assignment index is within valid range
        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= 20
        # Position coordinates are bounded by their type definitions
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].x <= 40
        assert positions[i].y >= 0
        assert positions[i].y <= 40

ensure_item_assignment_and_position_uniqueness(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

    x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
):

        assert pos.x >= 0
        assert pos.y >= 0

    # Ensure each item is assigned to a valid box

        assert item_box_assignments[i] <= 20

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments : Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

objective:
# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
                       nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=0, ub=20)):
    # The objective is to minimize the number of boxes used
    # We need to calculate nr_used_boxes based on item_box_assignments
    max_assigned_box : int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if item_box_assignments[i] > max_assigned_box:
            max_assigned_box = item_box_assignments[i]
    nr_used_boxes = max_assigned_box
    return nr_used_boxes

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments, nr_used_boxes)
minimize(objective)

def place_items_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),

):

    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert item_box_assignments[i] >= 1

):

        assert x_y_positions[i].x <= BOX_WIDTH - items[i].width
        assert x_y_positions[i].y >= 0
        assert x_y_positions[i].y <= BOX_HEIGHT - items[i].height
        
    # No item can overlap with another item in the same box

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Get item and position
        item_w: int = items[i].width
        item_h: int = items[i].height
        pos_x: int = positions[i].x
        pos_y: int = positions[i].y
        
        # Ensure item fits within box boundaries
        assert pos_x + item_w <= box_width
        assert pos_y + item_h <= box_height
        assert pos_x >= 0
        assert pos_y >= 0

fit_items_in_box(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    n_items: int
):
    for i in range(1, 21):
        for j in range(i + 1, 21):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # No overlap condition: at least one of these must be true
                # i is to the left of j
                # i is to the right of j
                # i is above j
                # i is below j
                assert (positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x) or \
                       (positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x) or \
                       (positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y) or \
                       (positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y)

def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
):
    # For each item, ensure it fits within the box dimensions
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item is placed within the box boundaries
        assert x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        assert x_y_positions[i].x >= 0
        assert x_y_positions[i].y >= 0

    # No two items in the same box may overlap
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            if item_box_assignments[i] == item_box_assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping constraints
                assert (
                    x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= x_y_positions[j].x or
                    x_y_positions[j].x + items[j].width <= x_y_positions[i].x or
                    x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= x_y_positions[j].y or
                    x_y_positions[j].y + items[j].height <= x_y_positions[i].y
                )

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item placement respects box boundaries
        assert x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        assert x_y_positions[i].x >= 0
        assert x_y_positions[i].y >= 0

    # Prevent overlapping of items within the same box
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            if item_box_assignments[i] == item_box_assignments[j]:
                # Non-overlapping condition: rectangles do not intersect
                assert (
                    x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= x_y_positions[j].x or

        assert x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        assert x_y_positions[i].x >= 0
        assert x_y_positions[i].y >= 0

    # Prevent overlapping of items within the same box
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            if item_box_assignments[i] == item_box_assignments[j]:
                # Non-overlapping condition: rectangles do not intersect
                assert (
                    x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= x_y_positions[j].x or
                    x_y_positions[j].x + items[j].width <= x_y_positions[i].x or
                    x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= x_y_positions[j].y or
                    x_y_positions[j].y + items[j].height <= x_y_positions[i].y
                )

no_item_overlap_or_boundary_violation(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=0, ub=20)
):
    # Ensure that the number of used boxes is at least as large as the highest box index used
    for i in range(1, N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS + 1):
        assert item_box_assignments[i] <= nr_used_boxes

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments, nr_used_boxes)
